I have been a teacher for 20 years and have a varied perspective as an educator. I have taught on Chicago's South and West side, in the northern suburbs of Chicago, and currently at a high performing Chicago Public School. Currently, I have a son enrolled in private school and another son attending the high performing CPS at which I am employed. In twenty years I have worked, consulted, and observed in some of the neediest as well as the highest performing schools in the Chicago area. At the time of Obama's election, I was fortunate enough to be teaching in the Roseland neighborhood mentioned in Paul Tough's article. I believe I have an understanding of the reality of day-to-day life in a school setting. From my first day of teaching on the South Side of Chicago, I believed ans still believe what the article discusses. The article brought me to tears, hard flowing tears with the truths it contains. The article states,

“From a child-development point of view we know that being a child in a family at the bottom end of the disadvantage scale means that you’re going to be less likely to get the kind of parenting or other care-giving that will lead to good outcomes and more likely to face the kind of adversity that leads to bad outcomes. For children, these social factors make a big difference — not just in their current well-being, but also in their future economic prospects.

The article continues,

“Unfortunately, these social changes pose an enormous challenge to policy makers. Americans know how to use their government to remediate a certain kind of poverty. If a family does not have enough food to eat or money to survive, we know how to issue food stamps or cut a check. But when children are growing up in a home without the kind of stability and support and order that they need to succeed in life, Americans don’t always know — and certainly don’t always agree — on what we want the government to do. We generally agree that we want the government to help increase opportunity and social mobility. But we don’t like the idea of the government meddling in the home lives of private families. And so we’re in a dilemma: the biggest factor holding back social mobility for poor children may be one we don’t have a good strategy to solve — and it may be one we don’t feel comfortable even addressing at all.”
According to the article, research is starting to show the impact of the challenges schools have to manage with a child coming from a dysfunctional home. Once again, as the article states, “Americans don’t always know — and certainly don’t always agree — on what we want the government to do”.

Now you're making good sense when you write, "How much money has been spent in neighborhoods like Roseland with little to no impact?" Yes, we need to divert money from useless programs, programs that have proven ineffective over long periods of time, and channel that into our schools to give the students something in addition to the education that many find so boring. I believe, however, that our welfare system must be overhauled to prevent people from being on the public dole. When government gives people money with no expectation of work, there becomes a dependency on government that stifles initiative. I have a place in Long Beach, California. There is a public housing high rise right on the beach. What you want to bet that those people are not desirous of finding a job so that they can move out? This is what I am talking about. Our welfare allows people to become to comfortable (though not really comfortable) so that they lose their initiative.

The government has been "investing" in the education sector for 150+ years since the first public school system was created. THIS is where we are today, after pouring untold billions of dollars into it: a collection of educated students who cannot compete on the world stage in basic math, reading, and writing skills. You can blame that lack of "human capital", you can blame the Teachers' Unions, you can blame the school committees and the administrations, but the fundamental problem is: Government-provided and Government-controlled public schools.

Why do we continue to believe the Progressives when they tell us that more Government control over education is all that it takes to improve it? When it's clear that doing so over the last 150 years has made it worse? When will Americans finally learn that the Free Market and Capitalism - especially in education - works? Why does no one propose that experiment, when the Progressive experiment has failed so miserably?

Here’s my solution on how I believe the government can help.  I believe the smartest and simplest answer to effectively address this chronic and debilitating social crisis is to invest in human capital in our schools.  The government should invest in the education sector.  Children need the support of loving, high quality, competent adults.  Many children from struggling neighborhoods are lacking the consistency of a dependable adult in their daily lives.  In each classroom, in neighborhoods with high needs, why not ensure each kindergarten room has one or two certified teachers with three yes, three aides?  I propose approximately five adults in each classroom pre-K through fifth grade consistently, to help ensure the children are engaged and get the support they need and deserve.  Am I dreaming?  Nice thought but not realistic?  The cost is unattainable?  How much money has been spent in neighborhoods like Roseland with little to no impact?

If teachers unions were truly the problem facing our education system, then charter schools would outperform public schools. But, of course, charters schools do not outperform. Instead, they produce about the same outcomes as public schools do on average, especially when one factors in that far too many charter schools tend to skim the best students out of the public system and actively work to exclude children with special needs.

The reality is that, while there are certainly reforms of teachers' unions that could be made, our public education system faces numerous challenges, including:

* Administrators who are far too often incompetent

* A lack of funding for core educational programming

* Being asked to deal with the types of social problems created by abject poverty in far too many neighborhoods

* A political system that is far more focused on dismantling the public education system in favor of private interests that donate to politicians' campaigns, rather than on improving public education.

If we want to move education ahead in the US, we need to stop scapegoating teachers and public schools, and instead focus on how we can attract the best teachers and strengthen the public system.

There needs to be middle ground-- surely this isn't too had to see?

Teachers must demonstrate competence in the subjects they teach, as well as mastery of pedagogic and classroom management skills. If a teacher is found incompetent, s/he must be removed without regard for seniority.

At the same time, it's wrong to demonize teachers and the teachers' unions. Teachers and their unions are key actors in shaping primary and secondary education, and polarization accomplishes nothing. Michelle Rhee, former School Superintendent in Washington, DC jeopardized her own reform program by failing to establish a constructive relationship with teachers and their union. Rhee's record was a major factor in the defeat of Washington Mayor Adrian Fenty, and Rhee was replaced by Fenty's successor, Vincent Gray.

Related issues are parental involvement, classroom standards and permitted classroom behaviors. Charter and private school attendees typically have more supportive parents,more rigorous educational standards and stricter codes of conduct than public schools. As a result, it's typically harder to teach effectively in a public school. Unfortunately, many of the crucial factors can't be controlled by teachers in the classroom.

I do like solar and wind, but hydro has been unfairly neglected as a positive alternative to fossil fuel and natural gas. I suppose it will have to have some high-energy lobbyists invading DC before it gets the attention it deserves.

Unfortunately, traditional hydro power comes from dammed rivers, relying on rain and snowfall that just doesn't come.

However, there is nearly perpetual hydropower to be derived from the motion of the currents, the ebb and flow of tides can generate huge energy - we just have to be willing to do it.

Wind and solar is all we hear about. What ever happened to hydroelectricity? Our hydro generating infrastructure is in disrepair and generators are based on outdated and inefficient technology. Even so it contributes a much larger fraction of renewable energy than wind and solar combined, and it is currently one of the lowest cost sources. And unlike wind, solar and coal, output can be quickly and easily adjusted to match demand. Why do we hear so little about repairing and expanding hydro capacity?

Why vacillate? There is no doubt that it is past time to reevaluated nuclear energy. I've spent the past 32 years learning how superior it is to all other available energy alternatives.

In twenty years of searching, I have yet to find a single story of a person who has been injured because of exposure to used nuclear fuel. For something that is almost always accompanied by the adjective of "deadly" nuclear waste has not caused much harm.

Nuclear energy's major public relations problem is that it takes market share from coal, oil and natural gas. The wealthy and powerful people in the business of supplying those fuels have logical reasons for hating nuclear energy and doing all they can to spread fear, uncertainty and doubt about it.

They have plenty of friends in the advertisement supported media - like the New York Times, who have probably helped them to realize that one of the most effective ways to dis a competitor is to ignore it completely.
I'm glad you had the gall (as some might put it) to show your support for nuclear. America seems obsessed with dirty energy: this must stop, the sooner the better. Nuclear is a good way to go.
Of course, there is a finite amount of fissible material in our world....

Maybe it's time to take another look at nuclear energy.  I do believe we can find a way to safely dispose of nuclear waste. The technology is over fifty years old and it may be a better alternative than fracking the heck out of the earth.
